Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: Programming with Semantic Revision Requests

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Software development today is a social process, and the workflow of<br/>programmers is increasingly centered around discussing program<br/>revisions - that is, artifacts that document small, incremental program<br/>changes. Meanwhile, traditional research on testing, debugging, and analyzing<br/>programs focuses on one program version at a time, ignoring any preceding or<br/>succeeding versions of the same software artifact. The project's novelties<br/>are a foundational examination of program revisions and the investigation of<br/>automated techniques that cooperatively assist software-engineering teams<br/>with reasoning about them. The project's impacts are to enhance the way<br/>engineering teams collaboratively evolve their software and thus enable them<br/>to more effectively create secure and reliable software on which society<br/>depends.<br/><br/>The project's core contribution is defining the notion of a "semantic<br/>revision request" that enables treating program revisions as first-class<br/>entities for debugging and analysis tools. A semantic view of program<br/>revisions enables programmers to run or analyze the program revision (both<br/>before and after a change simultaneously), not merely each of the two program<br/>versions, as supported by today's conventional tools. By focusing on<br/>debugging and analyzing program revisions - not their individual program<br/>versions - the resulting tools come closer to capturing the intent of the<br/>programmer as they develop and commit program changes. The intended broader<br/>impact from a technical perspective is that these executable and analyzable<br/>specifications will supplement, or even replace, informal descriptions about<br/>how software systems evolve, by providing an unambiguous way to communicate<br/>high-level programmer intent.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
